title: What will be the US domestic box office gross in the opening weekend for the next James Bond film No Time to Die?
possible_answers: No Time to Die will gross as much or less than Spectre ($70,403,148)
No Time to Die will gross more than Spectre but less than Skyfall ($88,364,714)
No Time to Die will gross as much or more than Skyfall
correct_answer: No Time to Die will gross as much or less than Spectre ($70,403,148)
preds: Going back to my original forecast.

The approach that I took to estimating this forecast was the research and data. I stated that there is an 80% chance that the gross income for the movie No Time to Die will exceed Skyfall, then a 20% chance that it will be as much or less, then a 5% chance that the movie will gross less than Spectre. Skyfall made $88,364,714 in the first weekend of the showing. The reason that I believed that No Time to Die would exceed this is based on the UK’s first weekend showing gross income. The UK made about 28,891,250 in the first three days of releasing the movie No Time to Die. The reason that this is so big is because of the fact that the UK’s market size is extremely smaller than the USA. This is huge because of the fact that it leaves more of a prediction that the box office income will be extremely high coming into the first weekend of this movie. Another reason that I chose that the movie would exceed Skyfall is due to the fact that it is Daniel Craig’s last time acting as the character James Bond in the movies. People are most likely going to be more inclined to attend the first weekend's showings of the movie due to the fact that is the last time to see him premier in a James Bond movie. Due to these different facts, I believe that at the end of the first weekend, No Time to Die will outsell sky fall.

"No time to Die" will be releasing at a time when Movie theatres are still funictioning at a 50% capacity. And it has to deal with competition from streaming services which people find more convenient. 
But also Bond Movies have a huge fan following and they are aggresively advertising accross all markets. So there is a chance they willhave a better box office.

Used previous data on the performance of other two movies in their opening weekends. Also took into consideration that people have been waiting since April 2021 for this movie to be released which builds up anticipation. There is a slight chance that it will not perform well if people in the target audience of this film do not feel safe going to see this movie in theatres; however, I predicted that more people were wanting to get out than stay isolated given the current covid situation.

I believe that No Time To Die will outperform both Spectre and Skyfall in its domestic opening weekend. Whereas Spectre’s opening weekend grossed at £19.8 million in the UK and Skyfall’s grossed at £20.2m, No Time To Die dwarfed both with an impressive £25.9m in its opening weekend (https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-58788368). This shows that audiences are more than ready to head back to the theaters, as fear of COVID has greatly diminished in both the US and the UK since the COVID vaccine has become widely available to the public. In addition, some experts are projecting that No Time To Die could even surpass $100m in its opening weekend (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/04/no-time-to-die-eyes-100-million-domestic-box-office-opening.html). This is due to the huge opening weekend that Venom: Let There Be Carnage had, which grossed just over $90m in its opening weekend. This number is even more impressive due to the fact that the original Venom movie grossed just $80m in its opening weekend (https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/venom-2-box-office-no-time-to-day-1235026486/). Venom: Let There Be Carnage beat its predecessor by over $10m despite competition from other openings The Addams Family 2 and The Many Saints of Newark. No Time To Die, in contrast, has much less box office competition. In addition, No Time To Die scored 84% with critics and 87% with audiences on Rotten Tomatoes thus far, compared to Spectre’s 63% with critics and 61% with audiences as well as Skyfall’s 92% with critics and 86% with audiences (https://www.rottentomatoes.com/franchise/james_bond_007). Clearly, audiences and critics view Skyfall and No Time To Die on similar levels- and both films seem to be significantly more well-received than Spectre. Since this is Daniel Craig’s fifth and final film in the Bond franchise and it is the first Bond film in six years, it is clear to see why audiences would be eager to get out of the house and into the theater to see this critically acclaimed spectacle- helping it to surpass the mark of $88m set by Skyfall (https://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/movies/daniel-craig-s-era-james-bond-comes-end-no-time-n1280723).

No Time to Die broke post-covid UK box office records, bringing in over 25.9 million pounds in its opening weekend which is more than Spectre at 19.8 million pounds and Skyfall at 20.2 million pounds (data according to BBC). Noting that the UK is about a fourth of the population of the US and that films typically perform proportionally domestically would lead one to believe that the domestic box office gross will be around or exceeding $100 million. Along with this, No Time to Die is Daniel Craig's last film, concluding a 5 film series. This suggests that there may be increased draw to theatres for Bond franchise fans, also being the first Bond movie in 6 years. No Time to Die as received high critic reviews, totaling 83% on Rotten Tomatoes which compares to 92% and 63% for Skyfall and Spectre respectively. It is also important to note that the audience score, 87%, is higher than the scores for both of the other films. With the supposed increased threat of covid variants, some may claim that covid may dampen turnout to theatres, however other films have done well in theatres recently despite the state of covid restrictions. For example, Venom: Let There Be Carnage made over 90 million in its domestic opening weekend, suggesting that covid hasnt had much grasp on the market recently. It is possible that No Time to Die performs worse than anticipated in the domestic market as UK indicators may not be wholly accurate; however, I believe it is fair to assume that the newest Bond film will gross higher than both Spectre and Skyfall in its domestic opening weekend.

Because both Spectre and Skyfall are very susccessful  movie in the 007 series, surpassing them are already hard. With covid hitting, although many cinema are already reopened here in US, but considering 007 is a movie facing the worldwide market. There is still many other markets in the world have strict limit on public gathering. Moreover, people's way of entertaining has already changed after the pandemic.
As the question is closing tommorow I adjusted my figures again ( havent realized that beforhand) its close to par of two of three alternatives.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2021/10/06/box-office-can-no-time-to-die-open-higher-than-black-widow-and-venom/ It’s currently ahead of Spectre ($70 million in 2015) and is on target to pass Skyfall ($90 million in 2012) to be Fandango’s top 007 pre-seller

Because The United Kingdom and Ireland box offices accumulated $25.6 million over the opening weekend together, and they have around 72 million people in population, which is around 1/4 the size of the United States population, I would estimate that this movie will accumulate around, but not more than $100 million in revenue during opening weekend. This is the 25th and final James Bond movie, so I wouldn't expect a fluke in profits but that possibility is accounted for in my estimated 5% chance that the movie will gross more than Spectre but less than Skyfall.

I think it would have been hard enough for this movie to surpass Skyfall without COVID, but especially with COVID, there is little chance that it gets anywhere near Skyfall. Shang-Chi did not even reach Skyfall levels in its opening weekend, so I think it is fair to say that No Time to Die will gross less than Spectre in its opening weekend.
The last movie of the James bond series, no fans would want to miss out.

I have seen Spectre and Skyfall before and I think No Time to Die will do better. Also I search some information about the predict. It said "‘No Time to Die’ could hit $100 million during its domestic opening, box office analysts say". https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/04/no-time-to-die-eyes-100-million-domestic-box-office-opening.html

I looked at the UK-Ireland box office gross figures for opening weekend of the first four films in this series and compared them to US figures, developing an index which could be used as a predictor. I took the average “index” of UK-Ireland to US box office gross for the past four James Bond films and applied this to the film’s UK-Ireland opening weekend performance. This gave me a prediction of $97M.

My reasoning is that due to the global pandemic, movie theater sales have dropped pretty dramatically, and so I find it less likely that with such odds a movie would do better than its predecessors which were released during “normal” times as blockbuster releases.  Additionally, there has been some social/political back and forth about making James Bond a woman or keeping him a man – I think this is less relevant but an interesting point for consideration. For many people the “culture war” in our increasingly polarized nation/world is kind of exhausting and makes people who historically tuned in to certain media less likely to continue doing so. We’ve seen similar trends with the politicization of sports. Sources of pleasure, recreation, and enjoyment are not as popular when they become politicized.

It’s also right on par (in market to market exchange rates) with Skyfall’s overseas launch and down just 17% from Spectre. I was never expecting this one to approach Skyfall ($304 million domestic and $1.11 billion worldwide)-level grosses. Anything close to Casino Royale or Quantum of Solace (over/under $600 million), let alone Spectre ($200 million from a $70 million debut and $881 million worldwide) would be a victory for EON and friend. https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2021/10/03/box-office-james-bond-daniel-craig-no-time-to-die-119m-addams-family-sopranos/?sh=7b07846b16ea

Still holding first bin as the favorite only because the figures on the actual Box Office Mojo site is showing a number more conservative than the media (see asterisk below). And using 2012 numbers may not align with current British Pound and USD values due to inflation so any calculations I made containing 2012 data is pretty much useless for practical reasons. US performance for Skyfall and Casino Royale didn't perform more than maybe 2.5x the UK numbers though, so I would assume that No Time to Die will also perform no greater than 2.5x the UK opening weekend gross of 28.4M USD. If my forecast is untrue, perhaps this is a better explanation by @bdelfin: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1340945 Though I question the population scaling technique since this model does not work for previous Bond movies Casino Royale and Skyfall (the only ones I checked). *Some figures being reported in the media report numbers for the UK and Ireland. But it is unclear which part of Ireland since not all of Ireland is part of the UK. So calculating proportions would be tricky because we don't know whether to use Britain numbers alone, Britain and 1/2 of Ireland alone, or all of Britain and Ireland.

The UK and Ireland opening was $35 million for 72 million people. If that scaled evenly to the US population, it would be $160 million. While the US is not as big a market for James Bond (per capita), last week's opening for Venom was $90 million, which was more than Skyfall's opening in 2015. Plainly there's a huge pent-up demand for big-budget action movies in the US, and if a franchise like Venom with smaller coattails can pull in $90 million, Bond will do even better.
Looking at overseas numbers along with Venom 2 numbers, a 100m box office is totally possible. Combined with the endless chatter and hype around the movie, I am expecting a lot from this movie.

Talk of 6figure opening which would be incredible post pandemic.

This is Craig's final performance as Bond and the release of this movie has been delayed for months, building a great deal of anticipation. The movie has already broken overseas box-office records where it has been released, so it seems likely it will beat out its two predecessors.

Typically the Daniel Craig's Bond films have premiered later in the Fall (November), so using Spectre and Skyfall box office openings is a decent anchor point. However,  I do not think it will beat Skyfall's box office opening because of COVID.

I looked up to see when Skyfall and Spectre were released to see if that had an impact on their opening weekends. Skyfall was released on November 9, 2012, and Spectre was released on November 6, 2015. Both these films were released around the same time; therefore it makes it easier to predict the sales of No Time to Die. No Time to Die is getting released October 8, 2021 which is slightly earlier than the other movies, but still during the fall season. Also, people are ready to go back to theaters.
Current international openings are on pace to just beat Spectre. Still unclear if the domestic market will track the same, but beating Skyfall seems out of reach.
I don't think No Time to Die can follow up Skyfall, and probably not Spectre either.

I'm thinking there's a better chance of more then $70M since the box office takes have been much bigger with Space Jam, F9, and Black Widow, but 56% chance of over $88M is shocking to me. Updating my priors for a couple of realisations: 
1. These are nominal dollars, films gross way more now than they did in 2012. The highest grossing opening film in 2012 was Avengers at $207m, in 2019 it was Avengers Endgame at $357m.
2. The range of outcomes is wide, but option 2 is a fairly narrow band ($70m-$88m). It doesn't make sense for it to be the 2nd most likely outcome.

Pre-pandemic I would have (and I think I did initially) peg this as an almost certain "less than Spectre".  Now I'm not so sure, a big does of nostalgia is going to be right up people's alleys this year, and the October release should mean people are feeling safe being back out in public.

2020 estimates were $75-100 million for opening weekend.  My estimate is tempered by hesitance to return to the theaters after COVID-19.  https://www.boxofficepro.com/long-range-box-office-tracking-no-time-to-die-007-james-bond/
Covid fatigue.  People want to get back to normal life.

That weekend is Indigenous Peoples' Weekend/Columbus Day which typically gets a higher gross. In 2017-19, that weekend has averaged around $162m gross (across all films) according to box-office mojo.  Skyfall accounted for half of the box-office in the weekend of its release, which appears on the high-side for a single film. This Bond film is fairly highly anticipated and well known, and there's nothing else scheduled to be released that weekend at the moment, so seems fair to keep 50% assumption at the moment. So without COVID, it appears that an assumption of around $80-$85m seems on point. Judging COVID impacts on demand so far, 2021 Memorial Day weekend grossed just under $100m, which is about 40-50% of pre-COVID levels. If we get back to 80% demand by October, that's about $130m for the weekend ($65m for Bond), if it returns to normal, then about $162m for the weekend ($80-85m for Bond), if there is the "pent-up demand" everyone is going on about and it exceeds pre-COVID, then >$88m is feasible.

Looks like the crowd thinks things are pretty evenly distributed, but I disagree. @domdaniells points out that theaters are shut and I honestly don't see people clamoring to get back into theaters for movies even with a blockbuster event like a James Bond film. Here's what I see that is going for it and what is not. Against:
1. Theaters are not a place people are fighting to get back into - this is a luxury of normal life and COVID means that it is going to take some time to get back to normal levels
2. James Bond is well-worn and might suffer from burnout
3. Bond is not a family-friendly franchise For:
1. Daniel Craig is popular and this is his final stint as Bond
2. All-star cast for villains and writing should make a more interesting film
3. Social media buzz has apparently been lively
4. Delay in production and overall lack of films during pandemic means people want to see something good - it's been 5 years!
5. Daniel Craig has Casino Royale and Skyfall (supposedly two of the better Bond movies) to support his sendoff Trying to weigh all of these factors together, I come up with the most likely scenario being an opening weekend that is thoroughly solid for a movie, but not out of the park amazing. COVID is a serious thing to consider and only two films in 2021 have even grossed over $88M during this year and they opened at $31M and $47M on opening weekends. If someone is telling me that the film industry in 4 months is going to somehow start doubling it's take on blockbuster opening weekends, then I'd be curious what data or considerations are being used. Note: Gross Box Office = Price of all tickets sold to the film during opening weekend. So suppressing the number of people willing to go to theaters - via COVID and streaming services - has an impact on the overall potential for this metric. Back in a month or so to update based on any new box office data.
Covid-19 pandemic means many theatres still shut. Those that have opened have attracted smaller crowds than pre-COVID. Unlikely to bounce back to pre-COVID levels by start of October.

Most responses are talking demand side. Supply side is underrated here—there are fewer cinemas today than there were in 2012, way fewer than 2015. Lots of uncertainty; I would be surprised if No Time to Die tops Skyfall.
People are longing to get back out in the world

Expectation that covid-19 will drive demand above and beyond what normal demand would be.  Given it is a brand for teens and adults it will appeal to a large audience who are tired of being quarantined

Welcome to the new normal. The Western movies in principle have lost their magic touch, so my prediction is it will not top Skyfall. However, even for a brief period I suspect there is a small chance it may make more than Spectre because people will want to go out and spend especially at this early stage no matter what.

The american youth will be out in force to see their main girl Billie Eilish's themesong. Covid winding down along with the sunshine in October, the cinema will be welcomed back with open arms. Who knows, maybe the new flock of AMC shareholders will all want to cash in on their free popcorn and catch Craig's final Bond performance.
The habits have changed once and for all
Depending on restrictions and evolution of Covid

I'm skeptical because of COVID, but I assume by October it should be around normal. The rationale of my forecast is that the Bond films that do pretty well on opening weekend are usually in November or December, and I'm afraid a release in October will not only be in close proximity in time to some places that will not want to open their cinemas hard and fast, as well as October being far from the busy traffic periods that we see during the holiday season. With this logic, perhaps Skyfall was the ceiling, and No Time to Die will fall short but perhaps above average. However, this is reportedly Craig's last Bond film, with many stars in the cast and much hype during and after production. This will push ticket sales up. I leave about a 20% chance for bin 2 because the window between Skyfall and Spectre is large, but not large enough in relation to the full envelope of bond films' historical opening weekend grosses. https://www.the-numbers.com/movies/franchise/James-Bond#tab=summary&franchise_movies_overview=od3
I want to go all in.  But I expect to be well ahead of the crowd curve, until the final week before the question resolves.  So I'll settle hedge.
going against the crowd - last of daniel craig, cabin fever, needs a big screen and mates around to get the full effect and what else is there to do in November?
This is a total gut move for me; I cannot see any movie breaking any standard records in the immediate post-covid environment but sitting in the middle seems appropriate given its October opening.

The world has changed. Many people are afraid of crowds even after being double vaccinated. In fact, surveys show people double vaccinated are more afraid to go out than the unvaccinated. After a year of being told to be terrified we can't expect movie turnouts to compare to pre covid. Many major movies are being released directly to streaming services. Poll conducted May 6-8. 46% of unvaccinated comfortable going to movies. 33% of vaccinated. These numbers will come up by October when the movie is released, however, we can't expect them to go to 100%. Of course, discomfort in going out to a movie does not mean they absolutely won't go to the movie, but I still don't think we should expect pre-covid box office levels. In fact, if a movie is popular and someone thinks that the movie theater may be very full of people this could be more likely to trigger their anxiety.
https://morningconsult.com/2021/05/12/vaccinated-unvaccinated-americans-comfort-with-activities/ And also, of course, people have been going to the movies less overall.

The movie has been delayed due to Covid so perhaps that creates a bit more suspense leading up to its opening. This is supposed to be the final James Bond movie for Craig , and it's 2 hours, 45 minutes long which may not be a positive but could be with longstanding fans. I'm betting that it's a big success.
The franchise needs a new star.
